commitResults.messageTitle: Started on iP and did level 0
commitResults.messageBody: I renamed the chatbot from Duke to Yale. I created two methods: greetUser to greet the user and exitChat to display the exit message.
Created a echo method. It uses scanner to read a line of input from the keyboard and if it is not bye (ignoring case), it will echo back the input. If input is bye, will exitchat.

Upgraded echo method to list the task or add the task depending on input. addTask will add input into array of size 100 and increase size of array accordingly. listTask will list down task number and task name.

commitResults.messageTitle: Added ability to mark and unmark tasks as done.
commitResults.messageBody: First, instead of having all methods (greet, exit,echo) in one class, i seperated them into different class (taskmanager, ui). Then, i created task class that stores if its done and description. when user says mark a certain task, yale will put X in brackets and print out the task accordingly. when commanded list, for each task, will show in brackets if its done or not.

commitResults.messageTitle: Added support to track type of tasks such as todo, deadline and event.
commitResults.messageBody: created 3 more classes for todo, deadline and event. each were inherited from task class and each overrides to string accordingly. for deadline and event, split function was used to split the sentence into arrays of description of tasks and the time information. during "list", will list out the task type, if its marked/unmarked, description and the timing if applicable. Also changed the if-else structure of runChat slightly.

Changed the naming convention of some variable and method names to follow the Javaâ€™s camelCase convention. For example, in to inputScanner, line to userInput, task to taskList, index to taskIndex, listTask to displayTaskList, runChat to hancleUserInput

commitResults.messageTitle: I improved the quality of code.
commitResults.messageBody:
handleUserInput was quite long, so I refactored into smaller methods (processUserInput, processMarkTask, processUnmarkTask, etc.) to improve readability and maintainability.
instead of hardcoding array size 100, i put it in a variable MAX_TASKS to eliminate magic numbers.
added scenarios for invalid inputs and commands to improve readability.
added checks for empty descriptions and invalid task indices to prevent runtime errors.
tried to ensure each method operates at a single level of abstraction.

code will print error message for the various error scenarios such as when todo is empty, when deadline and event is in wrong format (dont have slashes), when the input is none of the existing features, when index of task to be marked/unmarked is not valid, when adding tasks after 100 tasks have been added, when trying to list when list is empty.
defined a class YaleException to represent exceptions specific to Yale. I added throwing exception to when todo is empty, event/deadline is in invalid format and when users input is invalid command.

commitResults.messageTitle: I replaced the fixed array with dynamic array using ArrayList<Task>. I have also created a jar file.
commitResults.messageBody: I also changed the other methods like addTask, displayTask, mark and unmarkTask accordingly as there is no more MAX_TASKS and taskcounter.

commitResults.messageTitle: created method to delete tasks from the list
commitResults.messageBody: in taskmanager, created a code for deleteTask, which removes a valid index list. in main code, ensured that if command begins with "delete", the command will be processed as deletetask
created a new file storage to load and save tasks. also changed event task deadline to implement getters. used dynamic arrays in taskmanager.

* branch-Level-6:
  created method to delete tasks from the list
  I replaced the fixed array with dynamic array using ArrayList<Task>. I have also created a jar file.

* branch-Level-7:
  level 7, save
delete function was missing, so added it back
According to feedback from TA.

- Extracted functionalities into separate classes for better organization and readability:
  - Ui: Handles user interactions and displays relevant messages.
  - Storage: Manages task file loading and saving.
  - Parser: Processes user commands and executes corresponding actions.
  - TaskList: Manages task-related operations like adding, deleting, and marking tasks.
find method is added in tasklist, parser handles find command and ui shows the matching tasks
